reviewText:
So, how can I summarise this game is 3 words? How about
PAY TO WIN

I’ve been playing this game long before it came to steam, for over 2 years now, and from what it was, the game has gone from good to bad to downright horrible. The only reason I still play is due to playing for so long that to abandon my progress would be impossible

The developers are horrible - they only add things in that benefit them financially. They never listen to the community.

The events are near impossible for anyone who doesn’t have the absolute latest tech, unless you like grinding for days on end just to win.

The BUILD TIMES are what make this game pay to win. It's worse than Clash of clans. It takes roughly 1-2 weeks to build a single end-game ship, and you need at least 5 to make a decent fleet. Your options are:

1.) Wait nearly 6 weeks MINIMUM for a single fleet of ships
or
2.) Pay over 100$ MINIMUM to instantly have that fleet

When your fleet eventually dies, you still have to wait 12-36 hours just for them to repair, per fleet. You can't repair multiple fleets, so a person who doesn’t spend money in the game can get a few days of repair in the course of half an hour.

Things is, its very easy to have someone destroy your fleet even with skill, because they recently added in ship crafting, which allows you to upgrade your ships. This makes it a “paper scissors rock” scenario, where fighting with the wrong fleet can lead to disaster, with 12 hours of repairs to you, and none to very little to your enemy.

Another small detail, THE GAME IS FULL OF CHEATERS.
There are many Chinese alliances (clans) that manage to use scripts to kill NPC fleets over and over again while they sleep, and Kixeye refuses to do anything about it because, as I said earlier, they only do things that benefit them financially.

FINAL THOUGHTS

DO NOT GET THIS GAME unless you have hundreds of dollars to spend in a game where the highest bidder wins, or unless you are very very patient

Okay, first of all, I have been playing Vega Conflict for nearly 3 years now. 4 years, if you count the other games made by the same devs. I have never spent a dime on in-game assets; I learned, survived, and thrived. Even with that, it's still difficult to be competative in such a PVP orianted game without dumping some serious money into in-game assets. Here are my 2 cents on this review.

I really love this game. Seriously. It's quite an exciting game. Simple at a glance, but underneath, it's actally very deep in terms of ships, tactics, and even politics. But can I recommend this game? No. Not anymore at least.

Why? Because of three major reasons that the developers never seem to learn from.
Pay to win      It does not matter if you're an absolute newbie that just got the game when it came out on steam, or an elite pilot who has been playing since the beta days 3-4 years ago, if you don't spend real life money on in-game assets (coins!), you're not going to have a great time, nor be very competative in PVP. reviewText:
Vega Conflict is a fun game depending on what you want to get out of it.  If you're a hard core PVP person, you definitely have lots to do.  If you're more of a loner who wants to farm ships, you can do that all day long as well.  There are millions of ways of configuring your ships and fleets so that no two fleets need to be the same.  The depths of ships, weapons, armor, etc is staggering.

The only thing I don't like about this game is that it takes forever to do things when you get to the upper levels.  Can only upgrade 1 building at a time, can only equip items on one building at a time, ships can take over a week to construct, etc.  It makes the game drag on at the upper levels.  But getting to those upper levels is a lot of fun.

I've also seen a lot of Negative reviews saying you have to Pay To Win.  This is a bunch of BS.  I haven't paid real money for anything and have had no problems.  Sure, I can't complete with the people way above me but I'm not supposed to.  Farm resources, upgrade, buildings, repeat.  I've never had to sit and wait because I didn't have enough resources.  Rather I wait because I'm waiting for a building to get done upgrading.  Sure, you can pay lots of money to make things finish faster but that's true for any game of this stye (e.g. Clash of Clans, Game of War, etc).  Or, you can level up more slowing and learn as you go and not have to spend a dime.

Try it out.  You'll probably get hooked.

reviewText:
Personally, I'd give it a neutral opinion if I could.

Basic concepts :

1 - You have a base, you build attachments and upgrade them, you build ship and upgrade them, you make research to unlock upgrades for ships and base.

2 - You have fleets that are used to attack and salvage neutral frets so you have resources to pay for your researches/builds/upgrades.

3 - You can join an alliance that help speed up builds/researches as well as being useful for dissuading others players to attack you (though being attacked and defeated only have minor consequences).

4 - You can attack other players for medals (I haven't understood this concept yet).


I mean, the game is good and reproduce the concept of many mobile games of this genre.  Its not a 4X game so if that's what you're looking for you should look elsewhere.  In fact, the game need more time investment when you start rather than later.  The more you progress, the more time you require to build/repair/research things (this can go up to DAYS and probably WEEKS even further).  This exponential time needed to build/repair/research things reduce the progression to a crawl after a few weeks unless you pay real money.

Does it worth it to pay??  I'm not sure.  I haven't and still play it around 20 minutes day in order to keep my base, my ships, my economy and my researches growing (slowly).  If you wanna go F2P and you can live with that you will appreciate the game. However, if you wanna reach leader boards and be competitive, be prepared to invest a ton a cash.

Recommended as a casual ''hobby'' to waste time.  If you really want to play a game in which things matter and you actually feels like achieving something, go for something else.

Game: Vega Conflict 8/10
Dev: Kixeye 2/10

The game is excellent and has a lot of potential...the developer is questionable. I have logged in via steam for the first time, actual hours played are closer to the 1k mark. Funds invested into the micro economy around $2k US.

For me to believe the devloper intends to make this a game with some longevity, key issues at the customer relations and marketting levels need to be addressed.  As is, you get the feeling that the plug will get pulled at any day. (If you have read this far, a little history check on the success of the developers titles shows a recurring pattern, get in, get money, milk it, drop it.)

Posts and questions regarding the future of the game are routinely deleted for being inappropriate. (Even when they are quite valid, and follow the forum guidelines.) I'm not a poster, but the regularity of this behavior can be seen on the forums while looking up info related to in game events.

The fleet combat is fun, ship design has great options without being to much to handle. The progression of fleets takes time. Many player based resources available to help educate the new bro.

I'd consider this EvE ultra lite, and will follow its development with some interest.  Ongoing issues between the developer and the playerbase (specifically over the developers Marketting techniques) will be a long term factor in this game's continued growth.

reviewText:
I've played this game since right after it started. Over 3 years. When it first started wow what a breath of fresh air. That was back when it was in Flash and before you could even relocate. Everything was simple then. You researched ships and tech for your base and fought along side your friends against others. Blueprints were introduced and the first event came around. All good still. I still enjoyed playing and felt like the company really wanted the best for the players in balance with still making money off coins. I didn't coin and you could still enjoy the game very much without doing that. Met some great people online and things still were good. Around a year ago their best Community rep left and that's when things went down hill VERY fast. Kixeye started making promises and not following through with them. Things were ♥♥♥♥♥ing ninja nerfed and that started making people realize things were changing for the worse. Communication happened with less frequency from the company and then the switch to Unity said goodby to Flash for good.

More new blueprints and features came along (a lot of which the community never wanted) and tweaks to the stats of ships and combat modules started muddling what was once a simple game. Events and mini-events started happening more often and most of the time the prizes were less than spectacular. Mobile was introduced and then things really went down the drain. Kixeye started offering discounts on in-game money and giving crazy bonuses to coin bundles. Alliance features were added a bit before the mobile was but mobile was the start of the official end of this game as I had come to know it. Coin to win had officially taken over the game. I still stuck around because I had been in the game for a while and had most of the ships and tech and had good friends. Events started getting very difficult to do with the enemy dealing out huge damage to those grinding for prizes. Several of the events were so geared towards coining that I didn't even bother. Now crafting" comes along. So begins the new grinding for parts that were tough to come across and would not drop when they were supposed to. People were getting upset. Answers to our questions were given a in a kind of blanket way and promises were thrown around some to never be fulfilled at all.

Fast forward to a handful of weeks ago and Kixeye informs us that there is going to be a "rebalancing." What that meant was that all the time we had been grinding for parts and making new upgraded ships
date: was soon to be rendered completely irrelevant. Every single ship was getting changed. Every. One. Shield energy was getting slashed and armor damage repair on heavy ships was about to go through the roof. Not only that
recommended: they said every ship class was getting their speed changed to match each ship in that class. So an easily researched ship was now the exact same speed as an event ship you had to grind for (in each class). Mass of items stayed the same but their energy/damage resistance went way down.  Many other similarly ridiculous changes are also to be introduced soon. The community erupted in mass disapproval of course. Overnight dozens of threads in the forums were posted and people were ♥♥♥♥♥♥. I've never seen so many thumbs down on the thread Kix released about the changes coming. It was easily 95% negative. So after that the founder of Kix did an online interview where he basically avoided all direct questions regarding how wrong this all was. The community managers haven't properly addressed this yet at all. Negative threads continue to show up dozens by the day and no proper response yet. Nearly everyone in the community hates this idea and doesn't want it. Free players and coiners alike. They don't care. They already released the first part of this "rebalance." Two more to come.\n\nDo not play this game. It looks great and had potential a few years ago but the company only cares about a flood of new money coming from mobile and has no desire to keep vetran players. They have ZERO long-term vision. They ignore the community as a whole and just do what they feel like. What started as a beautiful flower planted in fertile ground has since been dug up and replanted within a field of weeds where it's being suffocated to death. Avoid this company like the plague."

(if you have an existing Kixeye account, you have to start a new game through steam. Once you gain control over your base, you have to go to settings, account management and from there Link both accounts be careful to choose the right one since one will be overwritten)

-No effort being made to counter balance the spending of money
(meaning it is game breaking, even the introduction of the black market which was suppose to balance things out includes items which can be purchased with coins. At some point you were able to buy 6 resistor modules for coins but only 1 resistor module with blood amber)

-Latest cheater controversy
(players who have used scripts to very far into the game have been unbanned because they spend so much money on the game. a case had been posted in the forums where a player spend up to 9000 USD in a week on this game)

-Events to win special prizes in form of blueprints
(will be also a pro point so please don't get confused. The idea of events is great, but Vega Conflict events last for 3+ days. Which require you to grind for many hours at a time in order to get the main prize. The latest Warfront event introduced a 7th ship into a Vsec Remnants fleet. A regular fleet is limited by specific amount of mass and the amount of 6 ships you can have in it. The 7th ship was a carrier which with fighter squadrons, dealing guaranteed damage no matter what strategy you apply.)

-Sub point event ships incoherent with available Vega Verse technology or mass restrictions
(meaning that devs change values and give ships buffs to guarantee damage. They force players to spend money for repairs, instead of making events more challenging they are based on generating max profit)

-Many sectors but not a connected universe
(will be also a pro point. An alliance is locked to a certain sector for a week, but can jump to different sectors either on random jump, to an alli members location or a facebook & kix friend. This does not work for cross platform friends however so beware that all your alliance members sign up through one platform or create a profile which is then linked to a certain platform.)

-Sub point relocation of members / whole alliance (our alliance had to jump loads of times since we ended up fighting big alliances using coins in order to repair their ships and send them out again. You can spend 1000 coins if you need to jump out before your 1 week timer cools down.)

-The crafting option is broken
(drop quality has improved but reports from many players state that they still receive drops they don't need)

-Customer service from personal experience is good. But player posts of their experience is rather disturbing at times.

Pros:

-Huge player community
-You can create your own guild and form alliances with others (to some degree)
-Real time fleet battle
-Rotating events on a regular basis
-Many sectors you can jump too
-Crafting is available
-Customer support responds fairly quick if problems occur

Conclusion:

It is fun as long as you manage to fight alliances on similar or slighty better tech level but the latest emergence of mega alliances like UA, IVC and others make it very hard to fight a single alliance.

This game could be a lot of fun but it is on a downward spiral of becoming unpleasant to play for players who do NOT want to spend real money into this game.
I would instead recommend other upcoming titles like Massive Frontier, which is being developed by a long time player of Vega Conflict who got fed up with their business model or sign up for the Beyond Dark beta on BeyondDark.net

reviewText:
So lets just get to the review quickly.

Pros:

Art design: The look and feel of the game is much better than what it was in BETA.

Customization: They did a pretty good job adding in further customization options for ships, and that can only add to the strategy even further.

Alliances: In an MMO setting adding in something to bring in the community and work together only strengthens the product.

Cons:

Community: After an hour of gameplay, the community is very...very anti noob heavy. If you haven't got the money to invest in the games microtransactions to attempt to catch up to the higher levels then don't bother. Also don't bother talking or attempting at asking for advice...it will only for some reason enrage the vets further and make them camp your base and fleets. In a game designed to be MMO worthy...that will only discourage the majority of new players and also ruin the chance of building connections in game to keep those invested.

Microtransactions: This game has gone off the cliff when it comes to a money sink. The game in BETA had a decent amount of Pay to win but this has gotten ridiculous. It has gone into the Clash of Clans level of ♥♥♥♥ery.

PVP is limited: only 6 v 6 combat and even then there are few choices when it comes to what weapons to use. Again unless you spend a godly amount of time you will be eventually forced to put money into the game to keep up with competition in your systems. Since they refuse to move and add more noob friendly systems putting you into the thick of it surrounded by higher levels only discourages play.

Literally saying durin the tutorial that no base can repel all attacks is a bit wrong. Especially on a game that relies so heavily on resources. Not giving the player the ability to more easily repel attacks of the same level player is a bit of a con if that was what it was reduced to. Player griefing is huge in this game, and would not recommend playing it. Let this game die like it should and play a MMO space game more worthy of your time like EVE or O game.

Recommended ? Yes AND No.
-Extremely fun when you're a low level (first 10 hours)
-Okay when you're a mid-level (next 20 hours)
-When you're an end-gamer this game becomes more of a micro-transaction demanding game. (after 100+ hours)

Here's the breakdown;
5 USD gets you 500 coins, 100 USD gets you 12,000 coins (2k bonus)
1 coin cuts you down 3 minutes of repair time

One end-gamer fleet can go as much as 12-18 hours of repair PER fleet
Therefore its literally paying 2.5 USD each time your fleet gets destroyed, or wait a staggering 15 hours average PER fleet, you have 7 fleets.

To build 1 of those end-game fleets, it will probably take you a month. (one ship builds from 5-12 days depending on what you're building)


However if you're still making up your mind, then here's an actual live recorded footage by me caught in action between the top 20 alliances in this game just going at it https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ghwNRV_uTP0

A lot do recognize me as CODE Aldnoah in game, because i'm one of the best pilots around that spends the least while getting the most results (9 fleet kills in a row)

reviewText:
Word to the wise. If you put time into this, you will probably put more money into this than a season pass game. This game does not forgive mistakes, and it's sole goal is the long haul. It has a community of those who care far too much for the game, as demonstrated by the sudden increase of shitposts. But enough of that, here are the facts.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
--It's going to take about a year to get up to end gamer level at the most basic level.
--Most tech is based on weekly to bi weekly events, you won't be touching those for a while.
--You need to make allies, or learn how to play quickly if you want to catch up within a reasonable period of time.
--Building fleets and bases are an art unto itself. It takes time, the further you progress this turns from days to weeks.
--All progress moves forward unless the player itself deletes it.
--There are protections for new players, but also disadvanages.
--If you play this game, after a certain point, your weekends may be forfit until you invest in higher end equipment.
--You will have a significant learning curve and disadvantage until you recieve event tech.
--The game core dynamics have recently changed, you will have an edge if you can find a way to adapt.
--The community can be toxic as all hell, but they love the game.
--Like fight club there are 2 rules. The first is that there are no rules, and second is that you do not ask about the rules.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In short it's a fun game I've sunk plenty of time into, but it is going to be difficult for a newcomer to put their time into. It's not to say that there is a significant learning curve, but it is stacked against you in comparision to much easier MMOs.
Regardless, best of luck in the void rebels.

reviewText:
Now, for those complaining about the ingame microtransations, if you actually play the gane, you don't need them! Lots of people get frustrated and end up paying for those microstransactions, but I like to take my time and actually play the dang game. Now, let's get into pros and cons.

Pros:
-Has a lot of potential starting from the app (which I owned prior to this) and so this would probably get a lot of popularity from the people who already have the game. This means more players which means more fun.
-It is a long game, meaning it doesn't take you only about 5 hours to complete the game. This actually takes a long time to even start getting close to the end, and even when you do make it to the end, that doesn't mea the fun is over.
-Super addicting! I haven't paid any microstransations for either version of the game yet (App and Pc) which makes it more interesting.
-This is a new conscept. I don't know any other games that have similar ideas such as this one. Having being able to use several fleets at once is super awesome and I love that about this game. A lot of this game has originality, most of the designs are original and complex, which shows how much work the devs put into the game.
-It really gets you in the moment. A lot of games like clash of clans these days (im gonna be using coc as a referrence point for the rest of this review seeing as just about everyone knows about it) never actually make you play the game. It's just 10 minutes of attacking, collecting resources, and yada yada yada. After 10 minutes is over, you either stop playing the game or repeat the same thing tomorrow. This game isn't like that. A lot of people actually play this game for some periods of time like me and we actually do stuff to progress, instead of waiting 12 hours for an elxir collecter to fill up (coc referrence). Instead of mostly depending on my miners to mine out the asteroids, this game actually lets me use my fleets for other things other than attacking bases, which is one of the main pros about this game. That gives me a lot of time to go attack some cargo and actually gain resources and keep progressing even when I'm not offline.



Cons:
-Super long waiting times, kinda like Clash of clans. If you've played clash of clans, you know how long it would take you to upgrade, for example, a lvl 9 cannon to lvl 10. Just like clash of clans, you start getting multi-hour long wait times very early in the game, which I noticed very quickly as I played the game more and more.
-It's extremely frustrating when searching for cargo. One day, you get your lvl 15 (or something near lvl 15) fleet and go find some cargo. But, what do you see? Oh, yeah, 10 ROWS OF LVL 17, LVL 25, AND HIGHER just slowly heading towards the VEGA outpost. There are soo many cargo ships for higher lvl players which makes it harder to progress in the beginning. Now, this is not a *big* problem, but for me it's really frustrating.

Now, those are my pros and cons. Remember it's just my opinion. I would highly reccommend this game if you enjoy sci fi, fighting, and space base building. These are one of the few times I make reviews, but when I do, I make it for a game I really like, and so this is one of the games I chose. :D

reviewText:
Now, for those complaining about the ingame microtransations, if you actually play the gane, you don't need them! Lots of people get frustrated and end up paying for those microstransactions, but I like to take my time and actually play the dang game. Now, let's get into pros and cons.

Pros:
-Has a lot of potential starting from the app (which I owned prior to this) and so this would probably get a lot of popularity from the people who already have the game. This means more players which means more fun.
-It is a long game, meaning it doesn't take you only about 5 hours to complete the game. This actually takes a long time to even start getting close to the end, and even when you do make it to the end, that doesn't mea the fun is over.
-Super addicting! I haven't paid any microstransations for either version of the game yet (App and Pc) which makes it more interesting.
-This is a new conscept. I don't know any other games that have similar ideas such as this one. Having being able to use several fleets at once is super awesome and I love that about this game. A lot of this game has originality, most of the designs are original and complex, which shows how much work the devs put into the game.
-It really gets you in the moment. A lot of games like clash of clans these days (im gonna be using coc as a referrence point for the rest of this review seeing as just about everyone knows about it) never actually make you play the game. It's just 10 minutes of attacking, collecting resources, and yada yada yada. After 10 minutes is over, you either stop playing the game or repeat the same thing tomorrow. This game isn't like that. A lot of people actually play this game for some periods of time like me and we actually do stuff to progress, instead of waiting 12 hours for an elxir collecter to fill up (coc referrence). Instead of mostly depending on my miners to mine out the asteroids, this game actually lets me use my fleets for other things other than attacking bases, which is one of the main pros about this game. That gives me a lot of time to go attack some cargo and actually gain resources and keep progressing even when I'm not offline.



Cons:
-Super long waiting times, kinda like Clash of clans. If you've played clash of clans, you know how long it would take you to upgrade, for example, a lvl 9 cannon to lvl 10. Just like clash of clans, you start getting multi-hour long wait times very early in the game, which I noticed very quickly as I played the game more and more.
-It's extremely frustrating when searching for cargo. One day, you get your lvl 15 (or something near lvl 15) fleet and go find some cargo. But, what do you see? Oh, yeah, 10 ROWS OF LVL 17, LVL 25, AND HIGHER just slowly heading towards the VEGA outpost. There are soo many cargo ships for higher lvl players which makes it harder to progress in the beginning. Now, this is not a *big* problem, but for me it's really frustrating.

Now, those are my pros and cons. Remember it's just my opinion. I would highly reccommend this game if you enjoy sci fi, fighting, and space base building. These are one of the few times I make reviews, but when I do, I make it for a game I really like, and so this is one of the games I chose. :D

reviewText:
It's a good game, but start it up by being realistic.

It's free to play, but the company needs to make money, the people need to eat, pay their mortgage, and dress their kids for school.  They need money somehow.

The standard for F2P games is to limit expansion by time, and then they let you buy out of that time by spending money. Vega is no different.  It's not pay to win, but it's definitely play more if you pay.

Development of buildings, tech, ships, etc all start out quick but eventally take days.  Your first few weeks you won't even notice the time restrictions.  Buildings and tech only takes a few minutes.  Cheaper, smaller, ships repair instantly for free.

But as you progress, you'll find that one tech can take a week to research, but before you start you need to spend 5 days upgrading a building, and then after you're done researching you'll spend five days building the ship you just researched.    Oh, and you need six of those ships to build a useful fleet.

All of which can be avoided if you spend money, of course.  But it's not pay to win, it's just a quicker experience if you pay.  Everybody, coiners and not, are playing the same game.

If you do play, search on youtube for strategies, read the in game chat, and if you value your ships don't steal resources.

One of the better basebuiling games with a RTS starcraft-like arena or battle mechanic and also a PVP and PVE environment. It takes a lot of time to build anything or get a higher level. Play it casually, in-between your other games. So far, it's kept most of my interest constantly for 4 months now, and i spend more time on it than anyother games, albeit afk at times. I haven't spent a dime on this game and you have to get used to getting beaten on and outclassed by anyone that pays money. But I have thought about it, because the deals have looked pretty good.
The ships are diverse and the weapons and additional modules are all quite different and quite interesting. For instance, the energy weapons are short range; they always hit, the missles are explosive with medium range, and the projectiles are long range but slow. All types of ships include: the  all-around cruisers, the weapon loaded battleships, the evasive harriers, the pursuiting cutters, and the sniping destroyers.

Overall, not the best but a good game. You can quit anytime but I'm pretty sure it'll have a hold on you for awhiile.

I've seen people saying a lot of what I’m about to say in the reviews, but I thought I'd contribute anyway.

Although I have only played 3 hours of this game through steam, I have been playing on mobile for the last 2 weeks off and on every day. This brings me to the fact that you can play this game on mobile, as well as on PC, which is in my opinion a nice touch.

Vega Conflict is a free to play, MMO space sim with RTS elements and base management. It's gameplay consists of building a base that will withstand any assaults from enemy fleets, as well as building up your own fleets to attack other players bases. You gain resources by attacking other people’s bases, attacking NPC cargo or military fleets, or through stealing cargo from other players' recently defeated NPC fleets.

Base upgrades, research for new weapons, and building new ships take real time. At first, as it is with all F2P games, the wait is quick, and is softened even further by the fact that you can skip the build/research time of any process that is under 5 minutes. Your base expands quickly, as all of the build times are under 5 minutes and you can complete many upgrades in the first few hours of play instantly, with no wait at all. However, over time, the average wait time starts to increase, and eventually reaches the point where at a base level of 25, you are waiting multiple days for a building to upgrade. Due to the fact that there are multiple buildings to upgrade, each of which have multiple levels, all of which take 2 days or more to upgrade, it can get very tedious very quickly as you can only upgrade one building at a time.

Micro transactions are present, however you can get almost anything present in the game for free, over a very long amount of time. For example, if you want to speed up the researching of a new technology, the building of a ship, or the refitting of a building with new weapons and armor, you can either wait the allotted amount of time, or you can pay for premium currency and skip the wait.
